Award.AwardTitle: SaTC-EDU: EAGER: INCUBATE - INjecting and assessing Cybersecurity edUcation with little internal suBject mATter Expertise

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will develop novel ways to teach cybersecurity topics. It is challenging for computer science (CS) programs with limited faculty resources to cover the breadth and depth of the discipline. The challenge increases as CS curriculum guidelines places more emphasis on emerging areas such as cybersecurity.

For CS majors, the project will produce cybersecurity modules for injection into existing courses. This approach supports the CS curriculum guidelines as 63.5 of the 72.5 lecture hours in the Information Assurance and Security knowledge area are distributed across other knowledge areas. Each module will include learning assessments to track students' progress in achieving the cybersecurity learning outcomes while the project will use student portfolios for program-level assessment. A multi-college event will be organized to provide additional hands-on learning experience on cybersecurity topics.
For non-majors, this project will refine a cybersecurity course taught in an interdisciplinary manner to humanities and sciences students. This course goes beyond the traditional computer literacy course by covering topics valuable for making decisions about cybersecurity issues that may arise in the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this project was to develop a set of instructional materials on cybersecurity that may meet the challenging needs of a small computer science (CS) program. As a result, modules on eight cybersecurity topics, which were defined using the CS2013 Information Assurance and Security (IAS) outcomes, were developed and integrated into 12 undergraduate CS courses.

Our chosen approach to weave cybersecurity modules into existing CS courses, starting with the very first CS course a student would take, seemed to be an effective way for our students to learn the vital cybersecurity-related knowledge and skills. Evidence of this is found in our assessment of fourth-year students taking our capstone course. This assessment evaluated these seniors understanding of CS2013 IAS learning outcomes from Foundational Concepts in Security and Principles of Secure Design. Average class scores in Fall 2016 were 87% while in Fall 2017 they were 98.75%. Students assessed in Fall 2016 had only one year of CS courses with cybersecurity topics integrated in them while students in Fall 2017 had two years of such courses. In addition, anecdotal evidence from advising students during their capstone project indicates that more students are considering the security and privacy of the systems being developed during their senior project.

To date, aspects of our injection modules have been disseminated through two conference presentations, two publications, and two educator workshops. In addition, a public web site (research.lemoyne.edu/incubate) contains all of our materials, allowing other educators to use our materials, in parts or in whole, to enhance their integration of cybersecurity in their CS program. Feedback from the CS faculty participating in our two workshops identified a few themes: the value of our eight cybersecurity topics that clustered IAS outcomes; the possibility of integrating cybersecurity into introductory and lower-level CS courses; and the use of real-life examples in our injection modules.

Our student learning assessment (SLA) efforts in this project have been integrated into our institutional SLA plans. In particular, we’ve added a program-level student learning outcome (SLO) specific to secure software development (i.e., Le Moyne College expects its computer science graduates are able to “evaluate the security of computational solutions”).

Another goal of this project was to refine a non-majors course Cybersecurity for Future Presidents. This course was taught three times during our project and is intended to increase awareness of cybersecurity by discussing issues that affect society including digital currencies, electronic elections, cyberwarfare and message encryption. Pre- and post- class survey results indicated a positive shift in students’ self-reporting of their cybersecurity knowledge base. This course has been incorporated into the core curriculum of our institution and can be used by current and future students to fulfill their interdisciplinary studies requirement.
